data.title: Harold Lloyd's Historic Christmas Tree — A Merry Monument –
data.meta_description: Harold Lloyd's historic Christmas tree is a merry monument that transcends all time. Get a glimpse of Christmases at Greenacres
data.text:
What’s more, I love Europe. So I am not surprised that this photo makes such a profound impression on me. Afterall, the French-Italian Renaissance Orangerie with hand-painted frescoes as a backdrop has me equally arrested in awe as Harold Lloyd’s historic Christmas tree itself!

At the time when I first reached out to Harold Lloyd Entertainment, I had simply hoped to feature a single photo and small description in the story on Luxe Christmas Ornaments I was working on. I mean, can it get any more luxurious than this?! And yet, the more I learn about both the Lloyd family and tree, the more deeply captivated I become!

A Hollywood icon who celebrated Christmas as big as our originator, Wally Bronner himself?! And a [grand]daughter who is willing to share her family’s remarkable story with me?! … All things considered, Harold Lloyd’s historic Christmas tree simply has to have a place of its own here! And it promises to be better than any movie Hollywood could ever script!

Who Is Harold Lloyd?

Rising in the ranks at the same time as other greats like Charlie Chaplin and Buster Keaton, Harold Lloyd is, arguably, one of the most influential film comedians of the silent era to be sure! Lloyd made nearly 200 comedy films, both silent and talkies, during his film career which spanned from 1914 to 1947.

Known for doing all his own daredevil stunts, it’s easy to understand how Harold Lloyd was crowned ‘king of daredevil comedy.’ Ironically, one of his most notable characters, created to be more like Lloyd himself, whom he named “Glasses”, often masqueraded that bravery as the endearing, bespectacled, boy-next-door and everyman. So it’s no wonder that audiences connected so well with him.

“In his films, Harold would always get the girl, which [Granddaughter] Suzanne says makes him something of the father — or perhaps the grandfather — of the romantic comedy.”1

But Really … “The Boy” Gets The Girl

Appearing opposite of Hollywood’s prolific, leading everyman and hero — 15 times to be precise2 — was actress, Mildred Davis. Theirs was a romance that proved true, transcending from the screen into real life. And in a perfect prologue to the plot of their final film together, “Safety Last” — the two were wed on February 10, 1923.

A Second Act

It’s apparent that silent film stars Harold & Mildred Lloyd are leaving as remarkable a legacy on Christmas as in Hollywood!

The Magic Of Harold Lloyd & Christmas!

Christmas At Greenacres

We’re honored to be bringing you some of Suzanne’s most beloved memories of Christmases at Greenacres — the sprawling 45,000-square-foot, Harold Lloyd Estate located in the Benedict Canyon section of Beverly Hills.

FUN FACT – Placed on the National Register Of Historic Places by the United States Department of Interior in 1984, Greenacres is now a protected landmark.

Red & Greenacres

Harold’s decorating wasn’t just relegated to a Christmas tree! “He also decorated the outside of the house, which was amazing.” recalls [grand]daughter Suzanne.

“We had this waterfall that went from the top of the hill down Benedict Canyon. Which of course, you could see at night all lit up with lights.” Additionally, Suzanne fondly reminisces on a HUGE pine wreath which featured a beautiful bow and HUGE Santa Claus. “Everything was lit up and people would drive by Benedict Canyon all the time, back and forth. They would stand there and take pictures or go slowly by to see Harold’s [award-winning] decorations.”

Christmas With The Lloyds

It seems nothing was off limits … NOTHING! I can hear Suzanne’s voice animating with joy as she recalls a moment she’s about to share with me…

“Oh this is a WILD ONE” she gleefully proclaims —

A [Saks Fifth Avenue] Christmas Story

One Christmas, while accompanying Mildred and Suzanne on a shopping trip to Saks Fifth Avenue, Harold had spotted something. A HUGE, (and real) 12-foot, white, flocked Christmas tree, dazzling with jeweled ornaments in the store’s lobby bank.

“Well honey, that’s like going into a candy store with a child!” Suzanne jests. “And of course he had to buy some, so he went to find the manager.”

But the designer had made the tree for display and was unwilling to sell it in part. So Mr. Lloyd did what any collector does. He decided to purchase the whole thing … As a result, the day before Christmas Eve, the tree and decorations were carefully secured, to be transported to Greenacres, where it found its home in the entrance hall in front of the fireplace that Christmas.

I love hearing the spectrum of emotion running through Suzanne’s voice, over the phone, as she reminisces of days gone by.

All About THE Christmas Tree-Of-All-Christmas Trees

Let’s unpack the details of Harold Lloyd’s historic Christmas tree. First and foremost —

YES! The tree was REAL!

Well, more appropriately, the trees… Though so constructed, in the end, one could loosely argue that Harold Lloyd and his cohorts sort of pioneered a hybrid version of today’s real, artificial tree!

As Lloyd’s ornament collection grew, so did the need for a larger evergreen canvas! And so, over time, one tree was simply not enough.

“It would take about 2-3 weeks to put the tree up.” Suzanne recounts. “It started sometime around Thanksgiving. My [grand]parents would take me downtown to the train yards where the annual shipment of trees would arrive for the holiday season. We would pick out two identical, large Douglas firs.”

It was more than a tree, “there was construction to it. It wasn’t just ‘we’ll hang ornaments,'” explains Suzanne.

As a result of that ingenuity, Harold Lloyd’s historic Christmas tree survived the 1971 San Fernando earthquake, which measured a whopping 6.6 on the Richter scale! Surprisingly, without any damage!

Most importantly, “he had the tree totally fireproofed with this spray. It was kind of like lacquered hairspray. But it was for the tree, so the needles never fell off the tree. But the smell was still there.” Suzanne continues.

The Lloyd Family’s Decorating Bits & Bauble Tips

Working at the “World’s Largest CHRISTmas Store®, I found — what may be completely foreign decorating solutions or ideas to most people — actually incredibly familiar territory for me. Even so, in thinking of when these solutions were employed, in synch with a burgeoning Bronner’s, has me so fascinated!

I am convinced that if Wally Bronner had ever encountered Harold Lloyd in their lifetime, they most certainly would have been fast friends!

All About The Ornaments

As Suzanne shared, finding meaningful ornaments was a family affair – whether local or abroad. (And by family, we also mean friends and fans!)

“There was a charity group that my [Grand]mother Mimi belonged to called the ‘Assistance League‘ in Los Angeles and they used to make these incredible ornaments with these half plastic bubble cases with little miniature scenes inside of them — from the Virgin Mary, to Santa Claus and his sled to, maybe, an Austrian village to ballerinas. Oh! To toreadors…” remembers Suzanne. “It was just massive. And they’d make them small or really big. He [Harold] would give them orders … these were, you know volunteer ladies, not hired workers, that were doing them!”

“I think that it’s very special looking back that so many of his friends went out of their way to make ornaments for the tree to give him.”

Like Wally Westborn, his makeup artist. Wally “made him an ornament of this plastic bubble portraying Harold actually standing in his red bathrobe, that he wore a lot, trimming the tree.” I get the impression that this is, perhaps, both the most iconic and beloved ornament on the tree.

“So sweet …” Suzanne leads. “You know, fans would send him ornaments that they’d hand-made, or they’d done for the tree. And he’d make sure that a thank you letter had gone out and he’d sign it. … He LOVED that!”

Complimentary Color Coordination

Harold Lloyd’s creativity was not simply relegated to moving pictures. He also loved to paint and later became one of the first people to really start shooting in 3-D photography (in the late 40s). Lloyd “became a rep for the Stereo Realist Camera, and he shot about 200,000 photos.” Suzanne tells me. For these reasons, it’s easy to understand Harold’s particularity when it came to his Christmas ornaments.

Garland Beading Parties

Harold and Roy Brooks, “actor, secretary and adopted family member5” had this idea because the weight of the ornaments was too much for the bead garlands which were strung on cotton string. So they “talked my [grandmother] Mimi and some very prominent women in the film industry, and prominent society ladies — they all loved the tree and they all adored Harold, and they just thought this was really fun — to restring all the beads with 100lb fishing line,” recounts Suzanne. “So they did all the beading work. And they’d sit there with these needles and beads with their tea and tea sandwiches and then they’d get into cocktails and they’d just sit there and bead. And it was like, ‘hey, how many strings do we have today?!’ It was crazy, he had everybody doing them, even me!”

Lighting

“At some point he decided to ditch Christmas lights on the tree since you couldn’t see them through the ornaments. Instead, he used to spot the tree with spotlights.” remembers Suzanne.

Christmas Comes But Once A Year

There came a time in the mid 1960s when Harold was travelling a lot due to his considerable involvement with the Shriners and showing his films. And so the tree, which typically came down sometime in February had inadvertently made it up into July. (Because while he had help, Harold loved to be involved in every part of the festivities, even taking the tree down.)

Suzanne recalls what a pleasant shock guests would have that July when Harold would bring them to the sunroom to see his “Christmas In July” tree! The curtains were typically drawn and the doors shut, which meant that “the tree didn’t get a lot of exposure to sun or light or heat. And you’d open up the door and this whiff of pine …” She trails off a moment, as if reliving this memory. She continues, “And he’d turn on the lights and it was just — magnificent. “And it [the tree] just started getting a life of its own!”

While this didn’t immediately spawn the year-round tree, it did lay the foundations! And at the time of his passing in 1971, Harold Lloyd’s historic Christmas tree, which had then been on display year-round, about 3 years, remained up the following 4 while Greenacres was opened to the public as a museum. (Not surprisingly, the tree was always among the highlights of guest’s Suzanne informs me!)

Though the property tragically went to auction in 1975, and the tree was disassembled by Suzanne a final time, Harold Lloyd’s historic Christmas tree has taken on a life of its own that still sparkles today with same luminosity as he, thanks to his incredible documentation & [Grand]daughter Suzanne’s generosity!

“It was really a form of artwork, and a passion of collecting, and a passion of creating something so magical and spectacular — of grandeur. But a great happiness to it. And warmth.” says Suzanne Lloyd.

A Final Question For Suzanne Lloyd —

Is there a particular Christmastime memory or feeling that is special to you that you’ve not yet had an opportunity to share that you’d like to?

“I wish I could tie bows and do wrappings like my [Grandmother] Mimi because they were pretty spectacular. She wrapped some of the most beautiful presents I’ve have ever seen! … Her bows … you couldn’t top any of the bows she could make! She had a wrapping room at the house, you know for Christmas gifts.”

“I’ve got to tell you, every Christmas was very special. They made everything special.”

“But my [Grandmother] Mimi made it very special. I mean how the tables were set, how the flowers were done through the house. You know, all the relatives coming over. A lot of different Hollywood people would come to dinner, you know they were older Hollywood people whose children had grown up or they had lost their husband or this or that.”

“I think that it’s very special looking back on all of it.”

We wish a most heart-felt THANK YOU to Suzanne Lloyd for sharing her family’s incredible story and photos, here, with our community of Christmas enthusiasts! We hope you enjoyed this special feature!

Other Fun Ho-Ho-Hollywood Facts

Bill Strothers, Harold Lloyd’s costar in “Safety Last”, who did a lot of different stunt work for him, became a very famous, professional Santa Claus who could be seen in commercials for large brands like Kodak! (All that stunt work must have paid off since Santa does need to know how to get on top of buildings! Wink, wink. Check out his Spiderman abilities in Safety Last!)

Speaking of Hollywood stars and Santa … Did you know that on December 15, 1976, “The Duke” placed a call to Bronner’s Customer Service to order a Santa Suit?! We hope you enjoy this photo of Bronner’s CHRISTmas Wonderland originators Wally and Irene Bronner laughing with John Wayne!
